results.name: The number of partitions of n having the minimum number of summands such that all integers from 1 to n can be represented as the sum of the summands times one of {-1, 0, 1}.
comment: Define a feasible partition of an n-kilogram stone as an ordered partition of minimum possible m parts W_1 <= W_2 <= ... <= W_m broken from the stone such that all integral weights from 1 to n can be weighed in one weighing using the parts/weights on a two pan balance. The minimum m for any n is m=ceiling(log_3(2n)). This sequence gives the number of feasible partitions of n.
link: Md. Towhidul Islam, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..88573
Md. Towhidul Islam, Formula for number of feasible partitions of n

Md Towhidul Islam & Md Shahidul Islam, Number of Partitions of an n-kilogram Stone into Minimum Number of Weights to Weigh All Integral Weights from 1 to n kg(s) on a Two-pan Balance, arXiv:1502.07730 [math.CO], 2015.
formula: Let us suppose, a(0)=1 and for (3^(m-1)+1)/2<=n<=(3^m-1)/2, m=ceiling(log_3(2n)).
example: For n=3, minimum number of weights m is 2. The only "feasible" set of weights is [1,2]. So, a(3)=1.
For n=7, m is 3. The "feasible" sets of weights are [1,1,5], [1,2,4], [1,3,3]. So, a(7)=3.
mathematica: okQ[v_] := Module[{s=0}, For[i=1, i <= Length[v], i++, If[v[[i]] > 2*s+1, Return[ False], s += v[[i]] ] ]; Return[True]]; a[n_] := With[{k = Ceiling[Log[3, 2n]]}, Select[Reverse /@ IntegerPartitions[n, {k}], okQ] // Length]; Table[a[n], {n, 1, 88}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Feb 03 2015, after _Charles R Greathouse IV_ *)
program: a(n)=my(k=ceil(log(2*n)/log(3))); #select(ok, partitions(n,,k)) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Feb 02 2015
xref: When we calculate a(n) for (3^(m-1)+1)/2+3^(m-2)+1 <= n <= (3^m-1)/2 starting from n=(3^m-1)/2 backwards, we get the sequence A062051 which is also the triplication of the terms of sequence A005704.
